newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ shares end 20 points down, CHH, Lion depressed.
newsitem.headline: NZ shares end 20 points down, CHH, Lion depressed.

text.p: * New Zealand shares end sharply down
* Carter Holt Harvey depressed after Q3 result
* Lion Nathan under pressure. Reporting season uninspiring ---------------------------(Feb 11)---------------------------
Price movements at close
LAST CHG
324 -9 * NZSC cap index -9.97 at 5,096.87
360 -12 * Volume NZ$33 million. Futures -15 at 1,160 694 -4 * Other movers - -10 +3
A mid-reporting season malaise descended over the New Zealand share market with most leading stocks ending significantly lower on Tuesday.
The NZSE-40 Capital Index ended 20.28 points down at 2,310.00 as investors struggled to find good reasons to buy. Turnover, at NZ$33 million, was relatively light.
"Nothing is jumping out and saying 'buy me' at this stage," Nigel Scott at BZW said. "Overall sentiment is still pretty poor on very moderate to low volume," he said.
Leading the pack among the top five was brewer Lion Nathan which lost 12 cents to NZ$3.61.
Brokers said Lion was suffering after its main competitor, Foster's Brewing, reported robust earnings from its unit, Carlton and United Breweries, on Monday.
Fosters also reported it had 55 percent of the Australian beer market, indicating Lion had made little progress there.
Carter Holt Harvey's 53 percent plunge in nine-month profit to NZ$171 million was worse than forecast.
Furthermore, there was little in the short term commodities outlook for investors to get enthused about.
Fletcher Challenge "letter" stocks also failed to garner support.
Telecom, which made up a quarter of the volume, lost four cents to NZ$6.94 with one broker still as a still a net seller before its third quarter result on February 18.

Steel and Tube lost 10 cents after its result, but on very light volume. The company earlier reported a slight dip in first half earnings and said the current year's outcome was likely that for 1995/6.
Brierley Investments was the only leader to gain, rising one cent to NZ$1.32 in line with John Fairfax in Australia. BIL owns about 20 percent of the Australian publisher.
